message_1: What is the half-life of a radioactive isotope that initially has 100 grams and after 30 minutes has decayed to 25 grams?
message_2:
To find the half-life of a radioactive isotope, we can use the formula:

N(t) = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where N(t) is the amount of the isotope remaining after time t, N0 is the initial amount of the isotope, T is the half-life, and t is the time elapsed.

In this case, we have:

N(t) = 25 grams (remaining amount after 30 minutes)
N0 = 100 grams (initial amount)
t = 30 minutes

We want to find T (the half-life). Rearranging the formula to solve for T, we get:

T = (t * log(1/2)) / log(N(t)/N0)

Plugging in the values:

T = (30 * log(1/2)) / log(25/100)

So, the half-life of the radioactive isotope is approximately 15 minutes.
